name: Japanese Mythology
description:
The myth of Amaterasu hiding in the Heavenly Rock Cave
is one of the most celebrated stories in Japanese mythology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE).
When Amaterasu,
the sun goddess, sealed herself in a cave to escape her brother Susanoo's
violent rampage, the world plunged into eternal darkness. The myth explains the origins of sacred Shinto rituals, especially kagura dance, and illustrates how cleverness, cooperation, and sacred celebration can overcome even cosmic calamity.

name: Japanese Mythology
description:
The Creation of Japan
is the foundational myth of Japanese cosmology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE).
After the spontaneous generation of the first kami in Takamagahara (the High Plain of Heaven), the divine couple
Izanagi
and Izanami
descended to the primordial ocean and stirred the cosmic waters with a jeweled spear, giving birth to the islands of Japan and the myriad kami that inhabit them.

significance: Forbidden gaze motif - Universal mythic theme
name: Japanese Mythology
description:
The Journey of Izanagi to Yomi
is one of the foundational myths of Japanese Shinto tradition, recorded in the ancient chronicles Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE).
After his beloved wife Izanami
dies giving birth to the fire god, Izanagi descends to the underworld realm of
Yomi
to retrieve her. His journey reveals the absolute boundary between life and death‚Äîonce crossed, it cannot be undone without terrible consequences.
relatedConcepts: Orpheus and Eurydice - Greek parallel (failed rescue)
Forbidden gaze motif - Universal mythic theme

name: Headed Serpent
description:
The myth of Susanoo slaying Yamata-no-Orochi
is one of the most celebrated hero tales in Japanese mythology, recorded in the Kojiki (712 CE) and Nihon Shoki (720 CE).
After being banished from heaven for his violent behavior, the storm god Susanoo
descends to earth where he encounters a family terrorized by an eight-headed, eight-tailed dragon. Through cunning and courage, Susanoo slays the monster, rescues a maiden, and discovers within the dragon's tail the legendary sword Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi - one of the Three Sacred Treasures of Japan. This myth marks Susanoo's transformation from destructive chaos god to heroic protector.
